EXPERIMENT.TITLE: 16S Amplicon seq of simulation of gut microbiota: bacteria

DESIGN.DESIGN_DESCRIPTION: Standard library preparation for amplification of V3-V4 region according to Klindworth et al. (2013)

DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_TITLE: A comparison of the in vitro effects of 2-fucosyllactose and lactose on the composition and activity of gut microbiota from infants and toddlers
DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_ABSTRACT: Because of the recognized health benefits of breast milk, it is recommended as sole nutrition source during the first six months of life. Among the bioactive components are human milk oligosaccharides that exert part of their activity via the gut microbiota. Here, we investigated the gut microbiota fermentation of 2 fucosyllactose using short-term fecal incubations and the long-term mucosal simulator of the human intestinal microbial ecosystem with fecal samples from three month-old breastfed infants as well as two - three year old toddlers. A key finding was the strong and immediate increase in the relative abundance of Bifidobacteriaceae following 2 fucosyllactose administration by fermentation by the breast feed infant and toddler microbiota in the M SHIME. At the metabolic level, while decreasing branched-chain fatty acids, 2 fucosyllactose increased acetate, propionate and butyrate whilst gas production only mildly increased. Notably, consistently lower gas production was observed with 2 fucosyllactose fermentation as compared to lactose, suggesting that reduced discomfort during the dynamic microbiome establishment in early life may be an advantage along with the bifidogenic effect observed.

DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_TITLE: A comparison of the in vitro effects of 2-fucosyllactose and lactose on the composition and activity of gut microbiota from infants and toddlers
DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_ABSTRACT: Because of the recognized health benefits of breast milk, it is recommended as sole nutrition source during the first six months of life. Among the bioactive components are human milk oligosaccharides that exert part of their activity via the gut microbiota. Here, we investigated the gut microbiota fermentation of 2 fucosyllactose using short-term fecal incubations and the long-term mucosal simulator of the human intestinal microbial ecosystem with fecal samples from three month-old breastfed infants as well as two - three year old toddlers. A key finding was the strong and immediate increase in the relative abundance of Bifidobacteriaceae following 2 fucosyllactose administration by fermentation by the breast feed infant and toddler microbiota in the M SHIME. At the metabolic level, while decreasing branched-chain fatty acids, 2 fucosyllactose increased acetate, propionate and butyrate whilst gas production only mildly increased. Notably, consistently lower gas production was observed with 2 fucosyllactose fermentation as compared to lactose, suggesting that reduced discomfort during the dynamic microbiome establishment in early life may be an advantage along with the bifidogenic effect observed.

At the metabolic level, while decreasing branched-chain fatty acids, 2 fucosyllactose increased acetate, propionate and butyrate whilst gas production only mildly increased. Notably, consistently lower gas production was observed with 2 fucosyllactose fermentation as compared to lactose, suggesting that reduced discomfort during the dynamic microbiome establishment in early life may be an advantage along with the bifidogenic effect observed.

EXPERIMENT.TITLE: DNA-seq of human_adult male fecal

DESIGN.DESIGN_DESCRIPTION: The fresh fecal samples were collected from the healthy male crewmember, who is 30years old, just after a simulation of space capsule life for 33 days. Genomic DNA was extracted from the fecal samples with the PowerFecalÂ DNA Isolation Kit (MO BIO Laboratories, Carlsbad, CA, USA) following the protocol provided by the supplier (0.25 g of each fecal sample). The quality control DNA samples were stored frozen (-20çC) prior to use. Sequencing libraries were generated using the NEBNextÂ UltraČ DNA Library Prep Kit for Illumina (NEB, USA) following the manufactureręs recommendations, and index codes were used to tag sequences belonging to an individual sample. Clustering of the index-coded samples was performed on a cBot Cluster Generation System according to the manufactureręs instructions. After cluster generation, the prepared libraries were sequenced on an Illumina HiSeq2500 platform to generate paired-end reads.

DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_TITLE: The gut microbiome before and after simulated space capsule life
DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_ABSTRACT: There are four Metagenome Sequences in this project, which are FS.A0, FS.B0, FS.A33 and FS.B33. Two male crewmembers (A and B) lived in a high-fidelity ground simulation of a space capsule for 33 days. The fresh fecal samples were collected before and just after the simulation (FS.0 and FS.33). Metagenomic approaches were used to investigate the influence of living in a simulated space capsule on the diversity and abundance of the gut microbiota.

SAMPLE.DESCRIPTION: The fresh fecal samples were collected from the healthy male crewmember, who is 30 years old, just after a simulation of space capsule life for 33 days.

EXPERIMENT.TITLE: Illumina MiSeq sequencing of rumen microbe: in vitro fermentation

DESIGN.DESIGN_DESCRIPTION: Urea and acetohydroxamic acid (AHA, a urea hydrolysis inhibitor) were supplemented into the rumen simulation systems in order to explore the ruminal ureolytic bacterial community. The bacterial 16S rRNA genes were sequenced by Miseq high-throughput sequencing and used to reveal the ureoltyic bacteria by comparing different treatments.

DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_TITLE: gut metagenome Raw sequence reads
DESCRIPTOR.STUDY_ABSTRACT: In order to explore the ruminal ureolytic bacterial community, urea or acetohydroxamic acid (AHA, a urea hydrolysis inhibitor) were supplemented into the rumen simulation systems. The bacterial 16S rRNA genes were sequenced by Miseq high-throughput sequencing and used to reveal the ureoltyic bacteria by comparing different treatments.
